snippet.textDisplay: I have been using twist ties, two together,  for the nose area. They seem to work fine! You can sew through the part that is either paper or plastic, which holds the wire. Sew up and and down the sides and then zigzag the length of it so it will stay in place even if the the paper/plastic comes apart in the washing. There are no pipe cleaners available anywhere! The twist ties that hold together things like broccoli, kale etc. in the grocery store are all plastic and will probably hold up longer. I just wish I had been saving all the ones that I routinely throw away! Hope that this is helpful:-)
snippet.textOriginal: I have been using twist ties, two together,  for the nose area. They seem to work fine! You can sew through the part that is either paper or plastic, which holds the wire. Sew up and and down the sides and then zigzag the length of it so it will stay in place even if the the paper/plastic comes apart in the washing. There are no pipe cleaners available anywhere! The twist ties that hold together things like broccoli, kale etc. in the grocery store are all plastic and will probably hold up longer. I just wish I had been saving all the ones that I routinely throw away! Hope that this is helpful:-)

snippet.textDisplay:
Very effective homemade masks:
A mask can be made from a large plastic bottle so that it not only protects your mouth and nose, but also your eyes. You cut off the top and bottom of the bottle and then cut it lengthwise to open it. If you wear glasses, you can make two holes so that the things that the glasses have that go behind the ear (sorry, I do not speak English and I do not know what they are called hahaha) come out of the mask and you can put it on. If you do not wear glasses you can glue the top to a hat or tiara. These types of masks are very cheap, but most important: effective, because they isolate your entire face so that you not only do not get the virus, but you also do not accidentally infect other people.
After you used this kind of mask, you can clean them and use it again, this does not happen with the chinstrap because after a while they absorb droplets of saliva and they no longer work.

Well I do not know how many people read this comment but I hope it have been useful to someone.

Sending you good energy from the other side of the world!! and stay at home as much as you can!!! 💕🇺🇾


Máscaras caseras muy efectivas:
Se puede hacer una máscara con una botella de plástico grande de modo que no sólo proteja tu boca y tu nariz, sino que también tus ojos. Cortas la parte superior e inferior de la botella y luego le haces un corte a lo largo para poder abrirla. Si usas lentes podes hacerle dos agujeros para que salgan las patitas de los lentes y los puedas usar con normalidad por debajo de la máscara (pero luego que las patitas salgan y puedas ponerlas detrás de tu oreja). Si no usas lentes podes pegar la parte superior a un gorro o una tiara. Este tipo de mascarillas son muy efectivas porque son baratas y te aislan toda la cara para no sólo no contagiarse, sino que para no contagiar al resto sin querer. Además luego las limpias y las puedes volver a usar, esto no ocurre con los barbijos porque luego de un tiempo van absorbiendo las gotitas de saliva y ya no funcionan.
Bueno no se que tanta gente lea este comentario pero espero haberle sido de utilidad a alguien. Les mando buenas energías desde el otro lado del mundo! ! y quede se en casa lo más que puedan gente!! 💕🇺🇾

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi ,I was just watching your video ,and I'm going to subscribe to your Channel. I've been collecting the wires out of the Disposable mask ,and the ear loops, and sanitizing and washing and giving them to women that are making the mask.
I'm getting ready to make some mask too, I'm also saving some for myself as well .I like watching y'all videos ,to learn y'all techniques, I've been sewing for years ,I made my first suit in 1976. I would love to make the mask right, and up to safety guideline. Oh I forgot to mention ,when I remove the wires,and the loops from the Disposable mask, they already been used.

snippet.textDisplay: Unless these provide a complete seal around your face, it's a better idea to dictate the fabric onto your face as you can see when she puts it on, there's a gap between there. Meaning air can come through that area. Many don't understand that surgical masks are made FOR SURGICAL PURPOSES NOT REPORATING MICROSCOPIC INFECTIONS!!!! She didn't put a nasal clamping wire in the mask deeming it USELESS all this mask is doing at this point all this mask is helping is people who spit while talking!! If you're going to go out into public with this, you should add waaaaay more layers of fabric and tape it around your face. A bare bones mask should be difficult to breath through. People who wear this kind of stuff expecting it to help at all are idiots! If you must make a shitty mask of this kind AT LEAST PROVIDE A PROPOR SEAL AROUND YOUR FUCKING FACE

snippet.textDisplay: Look cute when the virus passes right through the cloth OR if you want a mask that can actually shield you way better: All you need is a bra, latex glove, a stapler and 2 rubber bands, and duct tape: First, cut the bra in half you only need one bra cup and cut off the strap and any lace or excess material only leaving the bra cup with its edges in place,   Cut through the latex glove all the way up, now strech that latex material over the outer part of the bra with the excess fingers facing the bra and tuck them under rest of latex cover (do not cut off glove fingers) ,  then staple the latex to the edge of bra from the inside of bra trim making sure you staple the smooth side of staple, to be on the inner part of course (because thats the side that is pressing against your face duh), and then a rubber band (size that works for you to keep mask snug), you staple each rubberband twice, that means once to the top corner and that same rubber band stapled to the bottom corner of the bra trim. Repeat this with the other rubberband on the other side. Now just use any color duct tape (about 3 stripes of tape to cover across the mask to give it a smoother appearance, because the latex may be a little bunched up and appear air bubbly in the center if you dont duct tape it.  and Done..enjoy
snippet.textOriginal: Look cute when the virus passes right through the cloth OR if you want a mask that can actually shield you way better: All you need is a bra, latex glove, a stapler and 2 rubber bands, and duct tape: First, cut the bra in half you only need one bra cup and cut off the strap and any lace or excess material only leaving the bra cup with its edges in place,   Cut through the latex glove all the way up, now strech that latex material over the outer part of the bra with the excess fingers facing the bra and tuck them under rest of latex cover (do not cut off glove fingers) ,  then staple the latex to the edge of bra from the inside of bra trim making sure you staple the smooth side of staple, to be on the inner part of course (because thats the side that is pressing against your face duh), and then a rubber band (size that works for you to keep mask snug), you staple each rubberband twice, that means once to the top corner and that same rubber band stapled to the bottom corner of the bra trim. Repeat this with the other rubberband on the other side. Now just use any color duct tape (about 3 stripes of tape to cover across the mask to give it a smoother appearance, because the latex may be a little bunched up and appear air bubbly in the center if you dont duct tape it.  and Done..enjoy

snippet.textDisplay:
One 2015 study found that cloth masks only blocked 3% of particles, compared with medical masks (which stopped 56% of particles) and N95s (protective against 99.9% of particles, the study found). Healthcare workers wearing cloth masks were significantly more likely to be infected with flu-like illness.

A 2013 study found that cloth masks made from cotton T-shirts, pillowcases, or tea towels should be used only as a last resort — they only filtered out a third of the aerosols blocked by a surgical mask — though it was found to be "better than no protection."

Common fabrics have pores too large for viruses, that are about 100 nanometer in diameter, and most airborne droplets that contain viruses. In contrast, the pore sizes of knitted fabrics are often measured in micrometers, which are 1000 times larger than nanometers.

According to the textbook Physico-chemical aspects of Textile Coloration, cotton pores tend to exceed 10-20 micrometers, or 10,000 to 20,000 nanometers.
snippet.textOriginal:
One 2015 study found that cloth masks only blocked 3% of particles, compared with medical masks (which stopped 56% of particles) and N95s (protective against 99.9% of particles, the study found). Healthcare workers wearing cloth masks were significantly more likely to be infected with flu-like illness. 

A 2013 study found that cloth masks made from cotton T-shirts, pillowcases, or tea towels should be used only as a last resort — they only filtered out a third of the aerosols blocked by a surgical mask — though it was found to be "better than no protection."

Common fabrics have pores too large for viruses, that are about 100 nanometer in diameter, and most airborne droplets that contain viruses. In contrast, the pore sizes of knitted fabrics are often measured in micrometers, which are 1000 times larger than nanometers. 

According to the textbook Physico-chemical aspects of Textile Coloration, cotton pores tend to exceed 10-20 micrometers, or 10,000 to 20,000 nanometers.

CDC also advises the use of simple cloth face coverings to slow the spread of the virus and help people who may have the virus and do not know it from transmitting it to others.  Cloth face coverings fashioned from household items or made at home from common materials at low cost can be used as an additional, voluntary public health measure.

https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/diy-cloth-face-coverings.html

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you very much for the tutorial! I made 2 today of these pleated w/ 1/4" elastic loops and random quilt quarters (I don't know what they're called, folded up small and come in cute prints).

I haven't bought fabric or sewn in over 4 years so I spent more time adjusting the machine than I did making these! It's a 20+ year old Brother machine, that I love. It's a starter/basic sort and it's the lightest one to lift out of my others that are older and require way more time hassling w/ settings.

I already own/wear fabric masks for years when I go out because health reasons, but these are my first two to ever make myself. I looked to see if you had a twitter, I'd @ you but I didn't see one listed if you wanted to see.
snippet.textOriginal:
Thank you very much for the tutorial!  I made 2 today of these pleated w/ 1/4" elastic loops and random quilt quarters (I don't know what they're called, folded up small and come in cute prints).

It's a starter/basic sort and it's the lightest one to lift out of my others that are older and require way more time hassling w/ settings.

I already own/wear fabric masks for years when I go out because health reasons, but these are my first two to ever make myself.  I looked to see if you had a twitter, I'd @ you but I didn't see one listed if you wanted to see.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you again [watched both videos].  I saw a tip from someone who said to have the mask fabric cut on the bias.  I don't know if that helps it stretch and fit closer or what, but now that I've found your videos I shall try bias and on the grain and see.  Someone mentioned how washing first creates a disaster.  I prewash and dry on hottest setting; sewing or serging around the edges first avoids dreaded thread nests. Plus the end user won't experience a mask that might shrink too much.  Yikes.   Have a great day!
snippet.textOriginal: Thank you again [watched both videos].  I saw a tip from someone who said to have the mask fabric cut on the bias.  I don't know if that helps it stretch and fit closer or what, but now that I've found your videos I shall try bias and on the grain and see.  Someone mentioned how washing first creates a disaster.  I prewash and dry on hottest setting; sewing or serging around the edges first avoids dreaded thread nests. Plus the end user won't experience a mask that might shrink too much.  Yikes.   Have a great day!
